famous quote:
There is no greater threat to the critics and cynics and fearmongers than those of us who are willing to fall because we have learned how to rise.
-Bren? Brown (in "Rising Strong")
Interview Text:
by Anthony Gurrola:

Blessed are the pure of heart, ..for they will see God.

As a survivor of sexual assault, this has been the thorn in my flesh.

This has been the battle against my identity.

That because of what was done to me, I am therefore not pure.

That didn't seem fair.

And it's not.

But neither is His grace.

I remember one time, my wife, my friend and I paid a visit to the International House of Prayer in KC.

With no intentions other than His presence, and no expectations other than maybe leaving feeling good, we went in.

We sat together for a bit, listened to worship, prayed, then the Lord told me to do something I was terrified of.

"Close your eyes for 20 minutes."

My heart sank. Immediately I was filled with anxiety.

"What if when I close my eyes, my wife and friend are gone?"

"What if I'm abandoned?"

"What if I'm alone?"

These were the thoughts running rampant through my head. They were so chaotic and violent. It felt like my soul was hemorrhaging.
If you have ever struggled with anxiety, you know the feeling.

Above my safety, I wanted to be obedient.

So I did it. It took everything in me but I closed my eyes.

Instantly everything was black. Void of color. No sign of life.

Then almost immediately after, what I saw forever changed how I live my life.

I saw eyes that burned like flames of fire.

Raging flames consumed my vision.

The darkness was lit up.

It was terrifying. More so than being alone was.

For the only thing scarier than being alone is being in the full presence of God.

But this is the fear I needed.

All of a sudden, I heard these words.

"Fear only me."

And just as soon as a closed my eyes, they were opened again.

The 20 minutes had passed like lightening.

What I hadn't realized at first was what Yahweh was doing in me.

At first when I closed my eyes, all I could see was black, then an explosion of orange. The flames were all consuming.

This was significant to me because the room I was assaulted in was orange.

And I'll never forget it.

He was healing what had been done to me and at the same time, doing a new thing in me.

He was making Himself more terrifying than anything abuse had to offer.

He was restoring my vision.

Whenever I would see a sunrise I was reminded of suffering.

Whenever I saw a sunset, I only felt pain.

He was purifying my heart.

So that when I saw the colors of fire, instead of seeing my suffering.

I saw Him.

Him in all His terrifying goodness.

Blessed are the pure of heart, for they will see God.

Even when you feel like your innocence was stolen.(like mine)

He says "You are already clean."

Even when I feel the furthest from purity, He doesn't hide Himself from me.

Blessed are the abused.

Not because it's a blessing to be abused.

But because Christ bears it with you.

If you'll let Him,

He'll take the weight.

He'll take the suffering.

He'll take the dirtiness.

He'll take the perversion.

He'll take the molestation.

He'll take the rape.

He'll take the trauma.

He'll drink the cup of their sin and your suffering only to bring you peace.

And if you were the only one, He would say you're worth it.

Blessed are the pure of heart, Because not matter what they have seen before, they will still see God.
Music Video Instructions: Picture this being how God loves us, and how we can love him.
